title: A circle is tangent to the x axis, the y axis and the line 3x - 4y +6 = 0. What is its equation? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let its radius be r since circle touches x axis, y coordinate of centre is +r or -r since circle touches y axis, x coordinate of centre is +r or -r Distance of centre from line will always be r so we can apply distance formula — Case 1 - centre (r,r) r = |(3r-4r+6)|/5 5r=6–r or 5r=r-6 r=1 or r=-1.5 Soln 1 : (x-1)^2 + (y-1)^2 =1 — Case 2 - centre (-r,r) r = |(-3r-4r+6)|/5 5r=6–7r or 5r=7r-6 r=0.5 or r=3 Soln 2 : (x+0.5)^2 + (y-0.5)^2 = 0.25 Soln 3 : (x+3)^2 + (y-3)^2 = 9 — Case 3 - centre (r,-r) r = |(3r+4r+6)|/5 5r=7r+6 or 5r=-7r-6 r=-3 or r=-0.5 (but r cant be -ve) — Case 4 - centre (-r,-r) r = |(-3r+4r+6)|/5 5r=r+6 or 5r=-r-6 r=1.5 or r=-1 Soln 4 : (x+1.5)^2 + (y+1.5)^2 = 2.25

A circle is tangent to the x axis, the y axis and the line 3x - 4y +6 = 0. What is its equation? There are four such circles:  Their equations are: [math](x-r)^2+(y-r)^{2}=r^2[/math] where [math]r[/math] is one of 1 or [math]-\frac{3}{2}[/math] and [math](x-r)^2+(y+r)^{2}=r^2[/math] where [math]r[/math] is one of [math]-3[/math] or [math]-\frac{1}{2}[/math]. I found these by solving the equation of the line for [math]y[/math] and substituting into one of the equations involving [math]r[/math] above and taking the discriminant with respect to [math]x[/math], getting, in each case, a quadratic in [math]r[/math] which must be zero for tangency (a double root). This gives a total of four values for [math]r[/math], two for each of the equations involving [math]r[/math] above.
